api/Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities.BusV.title: Class BusVolumePreference | Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities
api/Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities.BusV.keywords: Class BusVolumePreference Persistent volume configuration for an FMOD bus. See Persistent Volume Control for usage. Inheritance Object VolumePreference BusVolumePreference Inherited Members VolumePreference.InitializeOnEnable VolumePreference.DefaultVolume VolumePreference.Initialize() VolumePreference.ClearPlayerPrefs() Namespace : Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities Assembly : Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities.dll Syntax public sealed class BusVolumePreference : VolumePreference Properties | Improve this Doc View Source BusPath Path to the bus. Notice that changing this during playtime will not reset the previous bus' volume. Declaration public string BusPath { get; set; } Property Value Type Description String | Improve this Doc View Source PlayerPrefsKey Declaration public override string PlayerPrefsKey { get; } Property Value Type Description String The PlayerPrefs key which the volume gets persisted under Overrides VolumePreference.PlayerPrefsKey | Improve this Doc View Source Volume Declaration public override float Volume { get; set; } Property Value Type Description Single The current volume. The range goes from 0 to 1. Notice that setting this will both set the volume and persist it to PlayerPrefs. Overrides VolumePreference.Volume

api/Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities.FMOD.title: Class FMODEvent | Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities
api/Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities.FMOD.keywords: Class FMODEvent A ScriptableObject managing an FMOD event. Using this class it's possible to hook up one-shot events directly in the editor, e.g. in a UnityEvent , and across scenes. Inheritance Object FMODEvent Namespace : Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities Assembly : Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities.dll Syntax public class FMODEvent : ScriptableObject Methods | Improve this Doc View Source PlayOneShot() Play the FMOD event from position (0, 0, 0) Declaration public void PlayOneShot() | Improve this Doc View Source PlayOneShot(GameObject) Play the FMOD event from a GameObject's position Declaration public void PlayOneShot(GameObject origin) Parameters Type Name Description GameObject origin Origin of the sounds | Improve this Doc View Source PlayOneShot(MonoBehaviour) Play the FMOD event from a MonoBehavior's position Declaration public void PlayOneShot(MonoBehaviour origin) Parameters Type Name Description MonoBehaviour origin Origin of the sounds | Improve this Doc View Source PlayOneShot(Vector3) Play the FMOD event from specific position Declaration public void PlayOneShot(Vector3 origin) Parameters Type Name Description Vector3 origin Origin of the sounds

api/Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities.Focu.title: Class FocusManager | Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities
api/Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities.Focu.keywords: Class FocusManager Focus manager, which suspends and resumes FMOD on unfocus and focus. Simply add this class to a GameObject in your scene. This is particularly useful for WebGL. Inheritance Object FocusManager Namespace : Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities Assembly : Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities.dll Syntax public class FocusManager : MonoBehaviour

api/Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities.html.keywords: Namespace Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities Classes BusVolumePreference Persistent volume configuration for an FMOD bus. See Persistent Volume Control for usage. FMODEvent A ScriptableObject managing an FMOD event. Using this class it's possible to hook up one-shot events directly in the editor, e.g. in a UnityEvent , and across scenes. FocusManager Focus manager, which suspends and resumes FMOD on unfocus and focus. Simply add this class to a GameObject in your scene. This is particularly useful for WebGL. VCAVolumePreference Persistent volume configuration for an FMOD VCA. See Persistent Volume Control for usage. VolumePreference Base class for persistent volume control WebGLInitializer Initialize FMOD properly for use with WebGL. See Using FMOD with WebGL for usage.

api/Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities.Volu.title: Class VolumePreference | Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities
api/Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities.Volu.keywords: Class VolumePreference Base class for persistent volume control Inheritance Object VolumePreference BusVolumePreference VCAVolumePreference Namespace : Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities Assembly : Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities.dll Syntax public abstract class VolumePreference : ScriptableObject Properties | Improve this Doc View Source DefaultVolume Declaration public float DefaultVolume { get; set; } Property Value Type Description Single The default volume set when PlayerPrefs is empty. | Improve this Doc View Source InitializeOnEnable Controls whether underlying FMOD object should be automatically initialized on load. Set this to false when using WebGL to avoid interacting with FMOD before it has properly loaded. Set it to true on all other platforms. When set to false initialization can be triggered in 2 ways: When something calls Initialize() explicitly, e.g. WebGLInitializer (this is the easiest and preferred way). On getting or setting Volume Declaration public bool InitializeOnEnable { get; set; } Property Value Type Description Boolean Initialize underlying FMOD object and restore volume automatically on load. | Improve this Doc View Source PlayerPrefsKey Declaration public abstract string PlayerPrefsKey { get; } Property Value Type Description String The PlayerPrefs key which the volume gets persisted under | Improve this Doc View Source Volume Declaration public abstract float Volume { get; set; } Property Value Type Description Single The current volume. The range goes from 0 to 1. Notice that setting this will both set the volume and persist it to PlayerPrefs. Methods | Improve this Doc View Source ClearPlayerPrefs() Clear the volume setting stored in PlayerPrefs. Declaration public void ClearPlayerPrefs() | Improve this Doc View Source Initialize() Explicitly initialize the volume from PlayerPrefs. This will usually happen automatically when InitializeOnEnable is true , but you can also call this method manually for more direct control. This is e.g. useful for WebGL, where you must wait until FMOD has been properly initialized before interacting with Declaration public void Initialize()

changelog/CHANGELOG.html.title: Changelog | Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities
changelog/CHANGELOG.html.keywords: Changelog 0.1.2 Fix integration with Scene Groups from Games.GrumpyBear.Core 0.1.1 [VolumeSlider] Get rid of wrapping VisualElement Fix broken sample 0.1.0 This release brings almost no changes and is more about me restructuring the repository and how I release changes. This setup was heavily inspired by https://github.com/ibrahimpenekli/GameToolkit-Localization Keep Unity project for development in repo, but extract package to separate branch/tag on commit Drop support for Unity IMGUI 0.0.1 Initial release

index.html.title: FMOD Utilities | Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities
index.html.keywords: FMOD Utilities This package contains a collection of utilities for working with FMOD's Unity Integration . Installation Download and install FMOD Unity Integration Install this package using the Unity Package Manager using the git URL https://github.com/Grumpy-Bear-Games/Unity-FMOD-Utilities.git (I suggest copy-pasting this).

manual/fmodevents.html.title: Playing FMOD one-shot events | Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities
manual/fmodevents.html.keywords: Playing FMOD one-shot events FMODEvent as a ScriptableObject , which references a single FMOD event , and allow simple one-shot playback. These instances are very convenient to reference from e.g. UnityEvent s, and can make adding simple sound effects and UI sounds very easy without having to add StudioEventEmitter components everywhere.

manual/volumecontrol.html.title: Persistent Volume Control | Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities
manual/volumecontrol.html.keywords: Persistent Volume Control A common task for any game is to allow the player can adjust audio volume from a settings menu and persist this setting between play sessions. This package contain several components for making this easy. VCAVolumePreference and BusVolumePreference are ScriptableObject s for managing FMOD VCAs and buses respectively. Each instance manages a single VCA or bus , and persists the current volume to PlayerPrefs. VolumeSlider is a VisualElement , which renders a Slider bound to a VCAVolumePreference or BusVolumePreference for building settings menus. See the sample for how to build a simple audio settings menu.

manual/webgl.html.title: Using FMOD with WebGL | Games.GrumpyBear.FMOD.Utilities
manual/webgl.html.keywords: Using FMOD with WebGL Using FMOD with WebGL has some special requirements and limitations. FMOD must be initialized through an action, which comes from direct user input, e.g. the user clicking a button. All FMOD banks must be loaded before interacting with them. FMOD should be suspended and resumed on focus events to prevent audio glitches. See more details in Fix blocked FMOD audio in Browsers and Scripting Examples | Asynchronous Loading This package provides two classes for helping with implementing this right. WebGLInitializer WebGLInitializer handles initialization of FMOD and bank loading. Usage: Set InitializeOnEnable to false on all VolumePreference instances in the editor. Create an empty scene with a camera, a canvas and a button. Give the button a label like "Start Game" or similar. Create a new GameObject with WebGLInitializer . In the editor, configure WebGLInitializer . This is easiest done by clicking the "Fix All Problems" button. (Optionally) Style and decorate the scene any way you want. Save this scene and make it the first scene in the build settings . When started, WebGLInitializer will load the first scene asynchronously and wait for the FMOD banks to load. The button is kept hidden until both scene and FMOD banks are ready. When the player clicks the button, FMOD is initialized (thus fulfilling the requirement of direct under interaction), and switches to the real first scene. Important Make sure to configure FMOD banks to load automatically under Initialization -> Load Banks in the FMOD Settings ( FMOD -> Edit Settings ) FocusManager When a Unity application loses focus in WebGL, e.g. the user switches to a different tab, FMOD gets stuck playing the same sounds. FocusManager is class, which helps handle unfocus and focus events correctly by suspending and resuming FMOD. Simply add FocusManager to a GameObject in your active scene. Tip It's recommended to keep the FocusManager in a global scene, if you're using a multi-scene setup.
